An update on triage

With Concourse, there is always a lot of work to do. I personally would love to see some of the larger issues worked on today, but we (the Concourse team) have to choose our battles. A good chunk of our time is spent on upkeep, architectural improvements, and trying to identify the underlying needs across many feature requests so that we can make a lower volume of high-impact changes.

The long and short of it is that the amount of work to do ‚Äì both in code and in the community ‚Äì greatly exceeds the number of people available to do it. Concourse is a product that has the entire software industry as its customer ‚Äì including video game devs, mobile app devs, DevOps, and people who just want CI for personal side-projects. It‚Äôs a lot to stay on top of, but it‚Äôs something to embrace: it forces us to think in the abstract. It just takes time.

The main goal of these changes is to promote healthier discourse by setting expectations about the status of an engagement more clearly. Issues are concrete; they will be prioritized and finished at some point, by the core team or ‚Äì in a perfect world ‚Äì by a volunteer from the community. Discussions on the other hand are at an earlier stage in the process.

Discussions on the concourse repo will be used for for questions and support. These can be more open-ended than bug reports ‚Äì there may indeed be a bug, but there might also just be an answer or a better approach. The outcome of these discussions may be a bug report, an improvement to the docs, an answer to the question, or perhaps a new Discussion on the rfcs repo.

Discussions on the rfcs repo will be used for incubating new ideas. By eliminating the ‚Äúsolution-first‚Äù framing of feature request issues, we can begin to focus on the problems instead. The hope is that we can all more easily identify underlying patterns and try to form broader solutions ‚Äì whether they‚Äôre ones we need to plan, whether they‚Äôre already on the roadmap, or whether there‚Äôs simply an existing solution that needs to be easier to discover.

With these changes, we no longer have any need for the ‚Äòstale bot‚Äô as Discussions can just keep trucking along at their own pace. The bot has been terminated. Unfortunately, I removed its configuration before uninstalling it, causing it to assume the default settings and unleash its annoying comments across a slew of issues and pull requests, going out in one last blaze of glory. Sorry about that.

Improving RFC engagement

Some of you have submitted RFCs and haven‚Äôt received much feedback yet. I‚Äôm really sorry about that.

With v6.0 out and with the dust settling on the ‚Äúv10‚Äù roadmap, I am going to shift my role towards shepherding RFCs and getting back to writing code rather than endlessly planning and prioritizing. It‚Äôs been a long time! This will also eliminate the conflict-of-interest where I author RFCs and then prioritize them while neglecting others. Definitely not a trend that I want to continue.

Expect more RFC update blog posts soon!

Improving Pull Request engagement

Another area we‚Äôre always trying to improve on is Pull Request engagement. We‚Äôve been tried a lot of things, but in the end it‚Äôs been hard to integrate into our day-to-day pairing process and escape the single-point-of-failure (cough me).

We‚Äôre going to start assigning each and every PR to someone on the team and dedicate half of each day to PR review. Our goal is to dramatically shorten the feedback cycle time and not leave anyone hanging.

What about discuss.concourse-ci.org?

These changes make our forums a little (ok a lot) redundant. Once the Discussions feature feels solid I plan to shut the forums down down and centralize our community in GitHub (in addition to Discord for real-time chat).

What‚Äôs happening with VMware?

VMware is heavily invested in Concourse ‚Äì in fact some of our recent significant contributions originated from VMware pre-acquisition.
